title: ‘Because you are the poors’: Curious employee wonders why Elon Musk can run multiple companies remotely but they can’t have multiple remote jobs
description: Hey, hey, let's all just take a deep breath, okay? There's no need to pile on the poor guy who's just wondering why he can't work multiple remote jobs like Elon Musk does multiple companies. Come on, folks, he's just asking a question. It's not an existential crisis; he's just passing through that adorable phase where all they say is "why?"—like a toddler trying to make sense of a very messy world.Now, sweetie, let's break it down for you. Elon Musk is the richest man in the world. and billionaires can do whatever they want. Why? because, well, they're billionaires. Why? Because that's just system we all agreed to. Why? Because let's stop right there.But when you, a regular software engineer, want to have a second remote job? Oh dear, that's a different story altogether. You see, in the real world that is not a billionaire utopia, rules apply to people.
author: Etai Eshet
excerpt: ‘Because you are the poors’: Curious employee wonders why Elon Musk can run multiple companies remotely but they can’t have multiple remote jobs - The internet has generated a huge amount of laughs from cats and FAILS. And we all out of cats.
text: But for you? No sneaking extra gigs, no playing video games at work. And generally, no peace nor quiet.So, don’t worry, kiddo; it’s not that you're wrong to ask—it’s just how the system is set up. Some people get to be superheroes; the rest of us just have to follow the rules and maybe dream a little less big. But hey, keep asking questions, not on company time of course. Musk has entire companies under his belt, a Twitter presence more prolific than an entire news agency, and claims to be a top gamer though, that might be a stretch. The thing is, people like him get to make their own rules. He doesn’t have a boss; he’s the boss of bosses. Why? Because he said so that’s why!
html:
But for you? No sneaking extra gigs, no playing video games at work. And generally, no peace nor quiet.

So, don’t worry, kiddo; it’s not that you're wrong to ask—it’s just how the system is set up. Some people get to be superheroes; the rest of us just have to follow the rules and maybe dream a little less big. But hey, keep asking questions, not on company time of course.

Musk has entire companies under his belt, a Twitter presence more prolific than an entire news agency, and claims to be a top gamer though, that might be a stretch. The thing is, people like him get to make their own rules. He doesn’t have a boss; he’s the boss of bosses. Why? Because he said so that’s why!
